entry.title: Echoing Dream
entry.content:
The sun does arise,
And brighten mine eyes;
Merry thoughts ring,
As I touch your rough skin.
I give you a nudge,
But you, heavy, won't budge.
I won't make a sound;
You my arms wrap around.
And my darling, you seem
My echoing dream.

You tangled my hair;
I laughed away care.
Your smooth pate I stroke:
Ah, now you've awoke.
So to start each new day
Has us often both say,
"Such such was the joy
Of which both, girl and boy,
In our youth time would dream
When we played on the green."
        
And our little ones, merry,
Will make us both weary,
But the sun shall descend;
Day shall come to an end.
In the arms of each other,
We, the father and mother,
Like children at rest,
Will begin our sweet jest.
And my love, you my dream,
Shall every night seem.

entry.title: Burning Bridges by AJ Garber
entry.content:
Walking across a burning bridge, the fire consuming it behind me with every step I take, I am left with no option but to plod precariously along its creaking wooden gangplank.  Looking out across the dark depressive distance I see a line of fire-lit bridges to either side of me stretching out into the horizon.  They are all swaying in the unpredictable currents of the innumerable weather systems that sweep across the skies; some hot and humid, others cold and biting.  A few carry a sweet successful scent while others stink of the failures of those it met before, like a man who has endured the company of a group of listless men in the pub and emerges into the street dirtied by the stench of their foul breath and the sooty smell of their acrid smoke.

Every bridge seems to emanate from a similar source and they all lead in the same general direction; some arc upwards, carrying the traveler towards some lofty destination, but getting thinner and ever-more precarious, while others would have me descend into the hollow depths of the abyss, which yawns widely beneath me.  Strangely, the deeper these down turned links between the destinations go the wider and steeper they become so that a person will eventually be at risk of slipping down uncontrollably, like a child whizzing down a waterslide with no foreseeable end, trusting only that the final stop will be a comfortable pool to soften the impact of landing.

Eventually I reach the bridge's end and hop off onto a small cliff edge on the side of a looming mountain.  All around it is dark, the only light being the inconsistent offshoot of the swinging burning bridge.  I kneel down on the rock and am surprised to find that it possesses a cold and rubbery texture - strangely familiar, but something in my mind prevents me from concentrating on ascertaining its exact identity.

"How do I go on from here?" I ask myself "I must continue my journey."  From the depths of the mountain an amused chuckle rumbles throughout the rock.  "You cannot ascend me, small one" the mountain states confidently "you are but an insignificant speck on me, a mere shivering blob of flesh and bone situated on my mass, cold and all alone.  Come!" it beckons, a large orifice opening up in the wall in front of me "you do not have to continue scampering about my surface; climb into that opening and in time you will become part of me"
As the brazen berg offers me a place in its temptingly solid mass, part of the rock to my right falls away and a bitter chill billows around me, frosty whistles whining in my ears.

I have to admit it is tempting.  I cannot remember why I set out on this odyssey and I do not know where it will lead me.  It has been so long since I was wrenched out of the comfortable, albeit somewhat poor, soil of familiarity, perhaps I should settle down? I have a place here, just waiting for me.  Sometimes I feel like life is an endless trepid trek across a million burning bridges and I tire so of the endless uncertainty in myself.  Everyone else seems to have found a nice little nook or a comfortable cranny to slide into, maybe I should as well?

Looking at the alien rock, I begin to discern faces in the extra light from the gap in the wall, peering out towards me.  Scanning the surface, it is as if the entire wall is examining me and evaluating my worth.  The faces share a uniform sort of sunken expression, united in their loneliness and competing in their regret.  They implore me to join their ranks but now is not the time.  "I am sorry that I cannot be part of your team," I explain "but my place is not here with you."  The faces suddenly become hostile and a sharp hissing fills the air.  I take a step back and look around for a way out.  Through that gap to my right I make out a narrow mountain path that winds around the mountainside, its embrace marking a corkscrew shaped trail to the top.
Up and up, round and round the mountain trail I stumble, stepping on the stone littered path.  The stones are soft and maleable, however, squelching and squashing against the pressure of my step and once I become used to their lack of resistance I begin to walk all over them with a certain playful delight.

As I come around the last bend I see a tiny man sitting at the centre of a crater in the mountaintop.  He is very thin, with a large scraggly beard but he dons a peculiar coat of stretched flesh, which he wraps tightly around his diminutive frame.  Perched nervously on a small stone stool, he surveys the activities below him with a greedy type of patience, like a man who sits in front of the television following the stock market reports with the air of a tightly bound coil.  As I walk up behind him, I see he is watching the people filtering down from the bridges, calling out to them through the medium of an ornately carved stone amplifier.

"Who are you?" I ask, unaware of our previous encounter.  "Me?!" the bearded midget squeaks in response as he spins around on his seat, then reminded by the comical pitch of his voice, clears his thin throat with its bobbing little Adam's apple and grasps his amplifier.  "Why I am the keeper of the Nocturnal Mount!  I am the lord of this empire of stone which stands firm against the currents which have always threatened to break it down".  As he speaks, the zealous light in his eyes illuminates our small cove and I realise that the mountain is not stone at all, but rather a tightly packed conglomeration of human flesh.  "What happened to all these people?" I gasp, wishing keenly to find a place untainted by the stench of the piled up misery.  He settles down and sighs with practiced patience before explaining in a matter-of-fact manner "you must understand, every time someone new arrives I offer him or her a place to settle.  If they do - they just have to sacrifice their bodies to my construction and in exchange they will receive the ever-lasting safety of belonging to a greater protective body."
"And if they do not?" I challenge, perhaps slightly more forcefully than was necessary.  He glares at me with disgust. "Why would anyone not want to stay here?  This is a wonderful place - you should be grateful I have offered you refuge!" He spits the words out at me, as if I have intentionally offended him - this of course allows him to wrap up in a coat of rightful anger, insulating himself from criticism.  "Besides" he whispers to himself "I need these people here to protect me from these horrible winds.  I get so cold sometimes…" he peeters off, snuggling in his familiar unhappy thoughts.  "But are you not exposing others to these very same winds in order to shield yourself?"  Looking down I realise that the moaning of the wind is actually emanating from the rock-bed itself; a dejected chorus of voices locked against their will but too frightened to set themselves free.

As I turn back to him, the little man summons up an ornately carved platform, which elevates him well above me, and of course as he rises higher, the surrounding walls rush up to envelope him from the ever-present winds.  "LOOK HERE" his over amplified voice echoes around my ears "I CREATED THE FOUNDATIONS OF THIS GLORIOUS MOUNTAIN WITH MY OWN TWO HANDS! THIS MOUNTAIN PROVIDES PROTECTION FOR ALL THOSE WHO DEVOTE THEMSELVES TO IT." And then he makes his descent "for with every new entrant" he continues in a softer tone which cannot be heard as easily in the surrounding area "the previous person becomes shielded by that person's body and because people will always run down towards me it is only a matter of time before every other person is taken care of."
"Besides" he reflects quietly as he returns to his original place "there is nothing on the other side besides a little ditch and some muddy water.  I saw it myself long before, that's why I started building in the first place.  At least here you know that one day someone will cover you..." He concludes, almost pleadingly.  I approach the far wall and search for gaps that will allow me through to the other side of this mountain.  All the bodies in the wall face me, their backs forever turned on what could have been.  Behind me the keeper becomes once more engrossed in the business of trapping hapless wanderers in his deceitful mound of misery.

Is there no other way to escape the rising tide than on the backs of those beneath us?  Is it necessary to insulate ourselves with the bodies of those less fortunate?  As I stand on the sickening squelching sea of sadness I get a sense of the suffocating weight of the masses lying below me and in that position I would do anything to break free of that shackle.  Still, I pity those supposedly lucky ones who rely on the misfortune of others for their own good tidings.  One day I feel this mountain will topple over, pushed down by the sheer weight of the millions all pushing together to escape each other.  On that day, those who have been on the outskirts of the group will find themselves on top and those who revelled in their claustrophobic cloak of corpses will themselves bear the brunt of the collapse.

I notice a small gap in the wall and peer through it.  On the other side I see a bright blue sky and in the distance rolling green hills.  "Come with me" I whisper to the frightened face in front of me "things could be so much better".  It murmurs quickly, wide-eyed with fear "I dare not, what if I don't find anything there?  What if I die in that muddy ditch?  I have a place here; sometimes it is not too bad…" His face solidifies into a resigned expression.  "I'm too old to go running around in the wilderness" he explains.  "Well, I cannot stay here any longer." I decide.
I grab hold of his face and tug it sharply.  He begins to slither out of the wall, like a slug squeezing through a hole in a fence.  Despite his initial resistance, he bends to my will and before long I am faced with a large opening.  The soft skeletal man from the wall immediately begins trying to crawl back into his palce.  Alarmed, I knock him out of the way and launch myself head-first through the gap. As I wriggle through the hole in the wall, the keeper turns around.  "Stop him!  He must not be allowed through, who knows what he might do to my foundations?"

I slide out through the hole and find myself rolling down the hill.  As I spin around and around, bouncing along the fleshy footholds it occurs to me that it might have been better to stay there.  Who knows what I might encounter out there?  “No matter,” I think to myself “I intend to meet the future on my own terms.” The bottom of the mountain approaches and I brace myself for the hard ground below.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I open my eyes to see a grey sky with tall rock walls creeping up haphazardly along the periphery of my vision.  As the minutes creep along, the make-up of my surroundings stumbles into my brain.  I must be lying in mud, because of the cool, squelching sensation, seeping through my shirt.  My arms and hands, bruised and grazed from the encounter feel stiff and cold while a thick grainy headache dances to the tribal rythym of my heartbeat against my unappreciative temples.  I allow my eyes to wander to and fro before I support their efforts with a grunted mobilisation of my head.
I am in a ditch of a rut.

I stand up and look at the ditch’s walls, looming above me.  Their coarse surface and jagged stones poking out makes ascending them an uninviting prospect, so I stumble along its length for some time.  This muddy burrow stretches out in both directions endlessly, like a claustrophobic narrow street, lined with dull and lifeless terraced houses.

My first attempt to climb out of the ditch is as disappointing as expected.  No sooner do I hoist myself up than I find myself sliding down onto my rear end.  I grit my teeth and launch into it again.  This time, I scramble up with some success but fail to reach the top, which stands only a short distance out of my reach.  Another attempt and another, each time getting a little closer to my goal only to lose as much ground as I have gained.  I sit on a mound to rest.
“What are you wasting your time for?”  a grave voice grates suddenly in my ears, like a grinding stone dragging along a driveway.  I look up.  “Who said that?” I ask, seeing no one.  A stone pings into the back of my head and I look around, my quick breath reverberating in my ears.
Warily, I look this way and that eying the walls suspiciously.  A mud-coloured man steps out of the ditch’s opposite wall.  He is tall, but bent as if the weight of life has forever pulled his shoulders down and his heavy feet seem to drive him into the ground with every step.  He moves forward towards me and drives a solid fist into my chest.  I fall back, gasping for breath, hurt more by the injustice of his actions than by his bruising medium of introduction.
“I am Concedo,” he states with slow, drawn out rocky resignation “and I am an old inhabitant of this ditch.”  Concedo’s face is hard and stoney, his brow lined with frowning cracks, his eyes semi-squinting and he has a hard edge to his fossilised jaw.  “I have seen all of those who have tried to pass through here, and it is always the same.  Everyone gives up in the end” he declares in a gravelly tone.
I stand up, maintaining a distrustful distance.  “Why do you hurt me?” I wheeze insultedly.
“Because I can, to show you that you are still soft.  You are here to stay, and your vulnerable skin shan’t help you here.  With time, you must learn to harden so that when you are battered the pain will not reach you.”
“But doesn’t that mean I won’t be able to feel anything?”
Concedo pauses as my question seeps through his cracks, trickling through him like a steady stream in the openings of a desert rock.
“Well,” he begins “that is true, but at least you do not feel any pain and you can get on with life.”

He sits down on a jagged rock, grinding its surface with his granite-covered body.  Sitting with his thick legs far apart and his heavy torso leaning forward he seems immovable.  I approach him cautiously and stand before his great face, with his large eyes so small under his thick frowning brow.
“How long have you been here?” I ask quietly.
“Ah... too long” he replies, with the unhurried air of one who perceives time’s passing in much larger segments than me.
“What do you remember from before?”
“Not much” he begins slowly, but as he speaks the words are like a boulder rolling down a hill; at first it is slow and moves only with forceful commitment, but his memories have piled up and the boulder can gain momentum on their downward slope.  “I came from a small, comfortable place.  Although there was nothing explicitly wrong with it, I always had a sense that it lacked the energy and excitement that I needed. It was good As accomdating as it was, it never seemed to feel quite right.  As my horizons expanded, its limited boundaries became increasingly constrictive and evenutally I felt an urge to find a new place, a bigger place.

I journeyed across the lands seeing and hearing many things, and the longer I travelled the more I regretted leaving my home.  However, the way back was barred by my need to assert my independence and besides, the temptation to find something better pushed me forward more powerfully than I was capable of resisting.  One day, my travels brought me to a bridge which climbed high into the sky and at its entrance there stood a promise that I would find what I seek if I cross it.  As I walked along its length, up into the clouds it became very dark and I thought to turn back, but as I stopped a fire began behind me, forcing me to proceed.  Eventually, I reached the end of the bridge, finding very little.  There were others like me, having forever left behind the familiarity of their pasts for the uncertainty of this future and we were all unsure where to go.  Just near the foot of the bridge we met a little old man with a strange coat who shivered in the wind, digging a great hole and promising us a place in his special home.  Most of them liked what he said, and having little alternative, joined him in his venture.”  He sighs and looks back towards the mountain in the distance “I do not know what became of them.”
He continues “I was tempted by his fantastical words, but there was something about him which deterred me from throwing my lot in with him.

I carried on past him.  I walked on, knowing not where I was going and stumbling over the uneven ground.  One day, I climbed to the top of a hill and on the other side I saw in the distance a beautiful land, which seemed to promise me all that I needed.  Without taking a moment to survey it carefully, I excitedly ran towards it, but I tripped over a stone in my path and fell into this ditch.”
“Did you try to get out?”
“At first yes, I desperately wanted to carry on my search, to find what there was out there, but I could never get over these walls.  There were other people here, who resented my energetic attempts to escape this place and they used to attack me with their hard firsts, knocking me down and sapping my energy.  I tried to convince them that there was more to life than their dull surroundings but they were too angered by their own incarcerations to contemplate  assisting someone before themselves.  Eventually, I got tired of scraping and banging against the unforgiving surfaces and jagged attitudes and I began to cover my body with mud, letting it harden.  The mud turned to stone and I stopped getting hurt by the flying rocks and angry people that dominate this domain.  Their attacks fell on my numb skin.  Now, having endured their exclusion I have been deemed worthy to take my place in their midst.”

I look around, struck by the silence around us.  “Where are your friends now?” I inquire.  “How should I know?” he snaps angrily “I’m not part of the inner circle yet, but if I am patient and I don’t push them, they will let me know in due time.  Why do you ask all these questions?  What do you care?”

His words die down, and the boulder rumbles to a stop.  I reach out slowly and stroke his rough face.  His great hand grabs my arm in a crushing, rasping grasp but I persevere painfully.
“I cannot stop here and neither should you.” I whisper “I am just as lonely as you were and I also want to find my home, but not here.  I can’t remember what it was I lost, but I need your help to find it.”
His eyes open up wide, and I see small blue specks in and amongst the background of his earth coloured irises.

He sighs a wheezing, cluttered sound and concedes quietly “sometimes, I feel terribly heavy, as if I am carrying an unnecessary burden and I wonder about that land I saw.  It is probably a dream, like the rest of my life, made up to bring colour into the grey and brown of my home.  I don’t believe that it is worth trying to leave my home; there is nothing good out there, only misery and pain.  At least here, the suffering is familiar and somewhat comfortable.”
My fingers begin to pull away small patches of rock from Concedo’s face.

As I reach through to him I feel the true Concedo.  He suffocates under his thick skin, wishing for a way to relieve his load but finding none and grinding on.  He convinces himself that he is rubbing away at the dirt until he finds a shiny new life, but I am afraid that he is simply grinding himself down.  I stop stroking his exposed cheek and his hold on my arm softens.

He stands up slowly.  “Alright,” he grumbles quietly ”I will help you, because if you remain for much longer I will become soft again, and I cannot afford that.”
He hoists up so that I can grab the rough top of the wall and pull myself out of the rut.  As I turn around I see him walking away and I call out to him.  “Wait, Concedo!  Let me help you get out as well!”
He turns and shakes his head.  “I dare not risk it,” he replies “besides, I am too heavy these days to manage.”
“But I can help you!” I cry.
“Not if I do not want to be helped.  Life has held too many disappointments for me to go chasing my stupid dreams, for I will only find another nightmare.” he answers and disappears into the rocky wall.

What else could I have done?  If he had listened to me, could I have given him what he lacks?  Is it possible to push and pull a person through life when they can’t do it on their own?  I wish I could, but then again, how far would I have been able to carry him before his weight pulled me down?
It is dark and I sit down under a nearby tree to rest.  The cold hours tick by, marked by my sighs.  The sun greets my face and I open my eyes.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The ditch is gone, it seems.  There is a muddy rut in the ground and a small hill just a few paces beyond, but the mountain and ravine are nowhere to be seen.  I turn around and look to the mountains north and south, the uninviting patchy land to the east, before making my way along the trail to the west.  From the tree onwards, gentle curving meadows expand out.  The gentle breeze ruffles the downy grass and tickles the flowers’ petals.

entry.title: Words Thoughts Dreams
entry.content:
You want to be heard, 
But you have no sounds to assemble, 
no verbs in your quiver, 
no arguments in your arsenal;
You're stuck in a queue waiting your turn
To plead with a drone on the phone
For a little compassion
But the only reaction you get
Is a jumble of anesthetic phrases
And the faint echo of the powerful laughing down on you.


You, you have no words to call your own.  
You have gestures and sounds, 
And a hand-me-down persona 
From our big brother across the ocean, 
Where everything of theirs is bigger, better, stronger, 
richer, faster, poorer, angrier, and emptier than ours.

You, you have no words to call your own.  
You know some, you adopted some, 
But you are not their master, you're their mouthpiece; 
You don't own them, you rent them, 
And pay more and more for fewer and less.  
You have feelings but no metaphors, 
You hold pictures but letters slide through your fingers, 
You can read looks but you can't read books -- 
Not in the way that allows you to say, "I understand and disagree", 
And not soak up resonant theories 
With tone-deaf ears 
To their discordant inferences 
And blatant untruths 
That worm themselves into your brain.

But come, there is still time, 
The passport to power is still within your grasp.
Here, take these words to heart,
Where they will be safe and protect you.


You can be ugly, you can be poor, you can be crippled, 
Knocked back, held up, pushed down, 
But no-one can look you in the eye 
And confiscate words that you won't hand over, 
For words give you ideas 
And ideas give you 
Strength to resist, 
Courage to dream, 
Freedom to be, to be, to be...

Not to be a no-one, not to be a number, not to be invisible, 
but to stake a claim on a space, 
to have a name, to have a face, 
to take your place amongst equals, 
to compete for first place if you want to -- 
if you can say it, you can think it, you can see it, smell it, taste it, touch it, 
from the depths of a squalorous cell 
to the dizzying heights and a galaxy of lights, 
your words can sustain your dreams, 
when everything shines with an oily glean, 
and all the world is dank and obscene 
you can remove yourself from this scene, 
and reclaim the latent reality in your heart.

If you can say it, you can think it, 
you can drink it in your sleep, 
you can find it in a heap of foiled plans and broken promises.

Come with me, and watch how others blame, and complain, 
And show the world how big and strong and brave they are, 
But they edifice is built on shaky foundations, 
Using borrowed blueprints, 
And when you try to wrench the words from the ether 
And strike them to ring forth with veracity, 
They will find their liberty bell is cracked 
And they are small, and weak, and fearful
In the forests of the night, 
When you face the tiger burning bright, 
And its beaming eyes meet theirs, 
And its bloody breath burns their nostrils, 
It will call on them to rise up 
And repel its ferocious challenge 
With a veracious onslaught .

And they, they will fall silent under its gaze,


But you, you will bare your chest and roar.

entry.title: Marriner's Lookout
entry.content:
The path to Marriner's Lookout had been difficult. The steep road was greasy and muddy, and the wind seemed to get in under his jacket. He had come to get away, but his mind kept tugging him back down the road towards the city. He felt a constant pinch between his shoulder blades.

When he reached the top of the climb he arrived at a gate; the path beyond the gate cuts through the mountainside, so he was partly shielded from the rain and wind. Along the left side of the path was a simple wire fence, and a few steps ahead he was greeted by two calves who watched him with patient hope.

“Hullo there,” he said, grabbing a handful of thick, wet grass that was just beyond their reach, “would you like a snack?”
The first calf looked away, but the second leaned forward eagerly and made short work of this treat. He grabbed another handful and while the calf chewed happily, he reached over the fence and scratched behind its ear. It didn't seem to mind. A few handfuls later, he gave the calf one last scratch and continued walking.

The path here was even muddier, and sections of it brought him back out into the wind and rain. Familiar, well-worn thoughts replayed themselves; memories of awkward conversations and uncomfortable silences returned to him; his neck and shoulders felt tight.

The bay came into view behind a screen of mist. As he passed underneath a large tree, the clouds parted and the sun broke through, its bright light quickly warming the air.

As he emerged from underneath the canopy and on to the final stretch, the mountainside turned emerald green and the sea a deep, rich blue. When he reached the fence at the top of Marriner's Lookout he leaned against it and cast his gaze over Apollo Bay. There to his right was a model harbour with colourful paper boats and a plaster-of-paris wave breaker; along the sandbox beach were clusters of bonzai trees; brightly coloured doll houses stood arranged in bunches while radio cars rolled mechanically up and down the pencil sketcher's streets.

He realised that he had been holding his breath. As he exhaled the tension released from his neck and shoulders. He settled cross-legged on the soft, thick grass; it was slightly damp, but he didn't mind. The ocean hummed with approval and the sun smiled down on him. The grass felt cool; its damp was ebbing.

He sat this way for some time, letting cold, damp thoughts evaporate, listening to the ocean's lullaby. His breathing slowed to the pace of the waves; he closed his eyes and lay back on the dry, welcome bed of grass. He put his hands behind his head and allowed his mind to be warmed by happy thoughts.

The ocean seemed to draw nearer; if he had opened his eyes he would not have been surprised to see it a stone's throw away, so close it sounded. The grass felt quite warm and firm, almost grainy, and when a took a handful of it, it trickled through his fingers. He sighed contentedly and allowed his thoughts to drift away.

As he lay in the sun, a soft weight encircled his waist and hips, and then it settled astride his thighs. A feather-soft touch began to trace playful lines along his stomach and across his chest. A sweet, natural perfume greeted him as he drew an unhurried breath and kept his eyes closed; as he exhaled he could feel his breath's passage blocked by something very close.

A shadow fell across his face and a thrilling, delicious weight pressed against his lips. He opened his eyes and a broad smile spread across his face. Her long, free, light brown hair shone in the sunlight and brushed his cheeks, and her scent filled his nostrils. He looked into her bright, excited, caramel eyes.

“I always knew I'd see you again,” he said. She laughed light-heartedly and put her finger against his lips; they responded with a kiss.

“Don't be silly! I've always been here,” she replied.

He frowned slightly and his eyes seemed to search for something just beyond his gaze.

“I suppose so,” he said, thinking out loud, “but I haven't been here for a long time. I've been somewhere very cold and rainy. I've been carrying something heavy, but I'm not sure where it's got to now."  He laughed as she ruffled his hair and tried to tickle him.  "I don't know where I'm going or where I came from.  It's so lovely here I can't even remember why I left in the first place,” he said jokingly.

Before his thought had time to fill the air she bent forward and smothered it with a long, assertive kiss. When she sat up he reached out and ran his fingers along her cheeks, then her throat, then her shoulders, and then her arms. She was wearing a green-and-gold summer dress with a thin, plunging neckline, and from where he lay he could discern the faintest hint of the outline of her breasts. She took his hands in hers and placed them against her chest as she looked up to the sky. The fabric of her dress felt warm and silky; her skin, cool and smooth and slightly wet with fragrant perspiration.

He looked up at her and familiar, well-worn thoughts replayed themselves; memories of awkward conversations and uncomfortable silences returned to him. He discerned dark rings under her eyes, and lines on her face that were not there before; her smooth hands felt slightly rough, and her hair seemed to have dulled like a meadow when a cloud passes over.

His smile receded. “I remember why I left,” he said in a clipped monotone. He felt her tighten and pull away slightly. He took a measured breath and tried to reassure her. “But it doesn't matter anymore: I've come back, haven't I?”

Suddenly, the royal blue skies darkened; a cold breeze began to blow. She looked down at him with watery eyes and her lower lip quivered.

“I'm sorry that I hurt you,” she said.

“Don't be silly!” he replied, trying to laugh light-heartedly.

“I should have known it was wrong,” she insisted, “I thought you would be pleased or amused, if I'd known I'd have never done it. I should have been more careful...” -- He tried to interject, but she talked over him -- “You just don't want me to talk about it any more, you want everything to be a happy nap on a sunny beach again. But it can't, it's different now, there's nothing I can do now, so what's the point?” She looked up at the darkening skies. “If only I had stopped myself, we'd still be together.”

“Please don't fret,” he found himself saying as his hands stroked her cheeks soothingly. “I'm not angry anymore; I just want you to be happy,” he heard himself insist.

But as the words left his lips a rusty pin pricked his heart and released a spurt of bile into his blood. It spread throughout his body, leaving twinges in his shoulders and a bitter taste in his mouth. His back began to ache and his head began to throb. The skies were now black and the breeze had been shoved aside by a biting wind. She shook her head and pushed his hands away; her body spasmed, her eyes welled up, and her hands clenched his powerfully; she leaned forward over him and as the wind wailed she cried, and the lightning flashed, and the thunder crashed, and the clouds poured out their hearts.
As her tears rained down on his face, the ocean's sound faded into the distance and the sand he lay on felt very wet. When he scooped a handful of it, bits of it stuck to his fingers.

“I shall always love you,” she promised and kissed him. Her tears trickled into his eyes and down his cheeks. He closed his eyes and tried to feel her warmth (he could always count on that), but when he opened them she was gone.

He sat up on the cold, wet, sticky grass of Marriner's Lookout and shivered as the rain washed away his dream.

entry.title: New Year's Dance

In a garden on a simple bench
On a sultry New Year's eve
A dance took place between us
To the music of the breeze
My heartbeat clapped the rhythm
As you beckoned me draw near
The hubbub seem to fade away
As my lips approached your ear
My right hand resting in your left
Your arm had made its welcome claim
I was free to swing and twirl
No fear of falling in your frame
Just the ever-present daydream
Of being swept right off my feet
With a tantalising movement
Executed to the beat
And indulgent recollection
Of the rare and cherished treat
Of being held
And being lead
And holding your attention
If only for a verse or two
If only when I hold your gaze
And am amazed to see the twinkle of the star
That I wish upon in bed
A touch before I rest my head
On my solitary pillow
And by the willow in my dream
I drift across a painted scene
While elderly couples recline
And reminisce and kiss
And as I drift back to the shore
I don't feel lonely anymore

But please ignore my wistful babble
No, please dismiss the things I said
My effervescent hopes
Must have gone straight to my head
Helped along for quite a while
By sips of port that make us smile
And with soft, illicit whispers
That rushed in like a tide
And left behind them blushing cheeks
And a crazy, foolish, silly thought
That caught in my mind
And wriggles around
And tugs at my shirt
And digs in my ribs
That maybe,
One day,
if you're free,
You might like to sit with me
And let me take your hand in mine
We'd put aside our charge of wine

And shrouded in each other's care
Underneath the starry skies
We could fill the summer air
With gentle whispers, hums, and sighs

As my escalator carried me down, and yours carried you up, our eyes met.

entry.title: Words Thoughts Dreams
entry.content:
You want to be heard but words are elusive; you have no sounds to assemble, no weapons to wield, no verbs, no action can arise, no energy left when you are bereft of a passport that anyone can give you and no-one can take; the more you use it, the more places you will go.

You can be ugly, you can be fat, you can be crippled, knocked back, held up, pushed down, but no-one can look you in the eye and confiscate ideas that you won't hand over, for words give you thoughts and thoughts give you freedom to be, to be, to be...

Not to be a no-one, not to be a number, not to be invisible, but to stake a claim on a space, to have a name, to have a face, to take your place amongst equals, to compete for first place if you want to -- if you can say it, you can think it, you can see it, smell it, taste it, touch it, from the depths of a squalorous cell to the dizzying heights and a galaxy of lights, your words can sustain your dreams, when everything shines with an oily glean, and all the world is dank and obscene, you can remove yourself from this scene, and reclaim the latent reality in your heart.

If you can say it, you can think it, you can drink it in your sleep, you can find it in a heap of foiled plans and broken promises.

But you, you have no words to call your own.  You have gestures and sounds, and a hand-me-down persona from our big brother across the ocean, where everything of theirs is bigger, better, stronger, richer, faster, poorer, angrier, and emptier than ours.

You have no words to call your own.  You know some, you adopted some, but you are not their master, you're their mouthpiece; you don't own them, you rent them, and pay more and more for fewer and less.  You have feelings but no metaphors, you grasp pictures but letters slide through your fingers, you can read looks but you can't read books -- not in the way that allows you to say, "I understand and disagree", and not soak up resonant theories with tone-deaf ears to their discordant inferences and blatant untruths that worm themselves into your brain.

And so you blame, and complain, and show the world how big and strong and brave you are, but your edifice is built on shaky foundations, using borrowed blueprints from the government, and when you try to speak the words of truth, to wrench them from the ether and strike them to ring forth with clarity and veracity, you will find your liberty bell is cracked and you are small, and weak, and fearful in the forests of the night, when you face the tiger burning bright, and its beaming eyes meet yours, and its bloody, burning breath fills your nostrils, it will call on you to rise up and repel its ferocious challenge with a veracious arsenal.

And you, you will fall silent under its gaze.

Words and Dreams

You want to be heard, but you have no words, no sounds to assemble, no weapons, no verbs, no action can arise, no energy left when you are bereft of the passport to success: you can be ugly, you can be fat, you can be crippled, downtrodden, pushed aside, but no-one can look you in the eye and confiscate ideas from your mind, for words give you thoughts, and thoughts give freedom to be, to be to be...

Not to be a no-one, not to be a nobody, not to be invisible, but to occupy a space, to have a name, to have a face, to take your place, to compete for first place if you want to -- if you can say it, you can think it, you can see it, smell it, taste it, touch it, from the depths of a squalorous cell to the dizzying heights and galaxy of lights, your words can sustain your dreams, when everything shines with in oily shean, and all the world is dank and obscene, you can remove yourself from this scene and reclaim the latent reality in your heart with your mind.

If you can say it, you can think it, you can drink it in your sleep, you can find it in a heap of foiled plans and broken promises.

But you, you have no words of your own. You have gestures, and sounds, and a hand-me-down persona from our big brother across the ocean, where everything is bigger, better, stronger, richer, faster, poorer, angrier, and emptier than ours.

You have no words to call your own: you know some words, but you are not their master, you're their mouthpiece; you don't own them, you rent them, and pay more and more for fewer and less. You have feelings but no metaphors, you grasp pictures but not letters, you can read looks but you can't read books -- not in the way that allows you to say, "I see, I know, I disagree," and not soak up resonant theories with tone-deaf ears to their discordant inferences and untruths that worm themselves into your brain.

And so you blame, and complain, and show the world how big and strong you are, but your edifice is built on shaky foundations, using borrowed blueprints from the government, and when you try to speak the words of truth, to really speak, to wrench the words from the ether and compel them to ring forth with clarity and veracity, you will find your liberty bell is cracked and you are small, and weak, and fearful in the forests of the night, when you face the tiger burning bright, and its beaming eyes meet yours, and its bloody, burning breath fills your nostrils, it will call on you to rise up and repel its challenge with an arsenal of words at your command.

And you will fall silent in its gaze.

entry.title: A Dream of Desire
entry.content:
In a cavern, all is white and empty.
A little door hovers in the distance.

[SECTION 2]

The air around me like a warm towel,
As my clothes unravel, melt and fade.
Outside, a banshee sings a lullaby.
Ankles kissing, hands clasped behind my back.

I close my eyes and wait.

[SECTION 3]

Soft fingers brush my right thigh;
Soft fingers brush my left thigh;
I keep my eyes closed.

An arm snakes around my waist from the right;
An arm snakes around my waist from the left;
Tremors as I raise my arms in welcome.

[SECTION 4]

Glistening nails caress my right palm;
Glistening nails caress my left palm;
Maybe I can pretend it is a dream.

[SECTION 5]

The hands on my thighs like slithering vines,
Creeping and tearing asunder my legs,
I try to close them...
Maybe I don't want to.

Hands on my waist become hooks on my hips;
Talons in my palms cut slits in my wrists.

[SECTION 6]

Oozing breath fills my nostrils;
Perfume clothes my legs;
Sweat adorns my chest;
Desire constricts my throat.

A flock of lips flutters over my breast;
Sings in my ears and breathes on my lips;

[SECTION 7]

Prickling,
Hardening,
Loosening,
Me.

[SECTION 8]

My legs and ankles in manicured manacles,
Biting the flesh of my thighs.
A corset of arms and clamouring hands;
A bit of silk between them and my pride.

[SECTION 9]

"Let's not go too far,"
I know I tried to say.
But my words are smothered by sweet, wet lips;

[SECTION 10]

And it tastes...
It tastes good.

[SECTION 11]

The corset of arms tightens its grip;
And a rough kiss grabs what's left of my breath.

I open my eyes and see them:
Beautiful and angry,
And hungry for me.

Why me?
What do they see?
Please leave me be.

[SECTION 12]

A jackal hand sniffs at my fraying shorts,
A pack of fingers feasts on its seams.
An army of hands and lips conquers me
And visits its Visigoth wrath on me.

I comply.
How could I not?

I look away and wait for my ending to begin.

[ENDING]

Sweet sleep come to me
Underneath this tree
Do father, mother weep?
Where can Lyca sleep?

entry.title: Package to 3442
entry.content:
Dear N,

I hope all is well.
There's so much to tell;
But nothing to say,
Since I went my own way.

Herein you shall find a stick with a chip,
With thousands of floating gate transistors,
Formatted to standard NTFS,
Although by me EXT4 would be
A better file system, more secure;
With in-built journalling for recovery
Of photos of us on a sunny day,
And clips of us kissing all morning in bed;
And line after line of raw sentiments,
Before they were compiled and found to have
Undeclared variables and hidden flaws,
Which failed under the unforeseen stress
Of our legacy run-time environment,
And the drain on our modest resources
Of startup tasks that we never asked for.

I wonder sometimes, during shutdown, whether
Our pre-releases could have been better;
If we had tested a little harder,
Could we have cleaned up the code a bit more?
But I think our source code was not too bad,
As it was, with all its faults and extra loops:
We could have corrected them in due course,
If our framework had been more workable;
If she had not been overclocked for nine months,
If the damn doctors had safely removed
That unstable, hungry, internal device,
Which should have long before been unmounted,
But for the Pentecostal clamouring
That the Church has an Microsoft patent
On who gets to live, and who gets to die,
And whose family gets to be ruined.

If only good advice had been followed
Early on in your project's life cycle,
Which, I admit, started underfunded,
But got so much funding from its victory,
Fought long and hard for, we would all agree,
That you could have outsourced all your grunt work,
And spent one-hundred-percent of your time
On the twenty-percent that you deserved;
Instead, you kept the QA to yourself
And stuck your ambitions on the high shelf,
And waited for your comfortable bubble
To burst one day and spatter everywhere,
Painting the picture in its true colours.

But I knew none of that on our first chat;
And if I'd known then what I have since learned,
I think I still would have signed that contract,
Because in hindsight you are still beautiful,
As you are, with all your funny drivers,
And occasional, forgivable segfaults.

If our source had been completely open,
And we had reported bugs without fear,
I might not have felt compelled to fork from you.
Because, in truth, messy code's not so bad,
If the ideas behind it have merit,
And the devs can agree on the language.

And one day, just maybe, I dream sometimes,
We could take more photos on sunny days,
And make many more silly mini-films
In bad lighting, with a cheap, on-board mic,
And upload them to an online album,
Where they'd stay afloat, all day, in the cloud,
While on the ground, we'd grow our own small LAN,
Just a couple squeaky Puppy lappies,
And then a server and a MythTV,
Then we'd have our very own LAN party,
And before long , we'd build our own distribution --
Ubuntu-based, filled with Python and PERL --
It would be stable, resilient,
Configurable and fun to improve.
And we wouldn't worry about precise input,
Because our command line would be tolerant.

And I?
Well, I would be more forgiving.

All the best;
You know the rest.

entry.title: Presumption
entry.content:
Hello there, hello there,
You look so well bred!
Would you mind if I proceed
To pat you on the head
And give your bearded cheeks
A condescending squeeze
And bore you for a while
In shooting the breeze?

This conversation has started so well
I have just a few things I'd love you to tell:

First, how old are you?
You know, it's so hard to say;
Your beard and your voice
Give nothing away.

What did you study?
What do you do?
Do you have any house pets?
A sibling or two?

Do you have your own car
(which your parents must have bought),
You look awfully fit:
Do you play lots of sport?

I sense you are musical;
Do you play the guitar?
How much did your parents
Pay towards your new car?

You sound ever so cultured
Does your family have great wealth?
You know I always say,
You've got to have your health.

You know, I have a daughter,
You two might like to meet,
She works in gift shop
At the end of the street.
She's doing her doctorate
On gender and race,
About how women executives
Are always displaced
By younger, more talented
Men, and increasingly women...
I don't know how she gets the numbers to bend
But her study proves women always get the sticky end.

But back to you darling:
Do you still live at home?
When you're asked to do housework
Do you mumble and moan?
Do you know how to use
A washing machine?
Do you rinse off your plates
When you try to keep clean?

And what beautiful curls
You have under your hat!
You know, women pay good money
To have hair like that.
Has anyone ever said
You look like that singer
With that hair and that nose
You could be a dead ringer!
And what do people say
About it being long and free?
I suppose you have a hard time
Being taken seriously.
And in the summer I imagine
It must get awfully hot;
Has anyone taught you
How to comb out a knot?
I wonder what sort of
Conditioner you've bought;
But, honestly, darling,
You should cut it short.

And those shoes, honey, please,
They're not even leather!
You need to go shopping.
Ooh, we could go together!

Young men these days,
They haven't a clue.
Which reminds, I wonder,
How old are you?

You look a bit tired,
Sorry, did you just yawn?
Has it got past your bed time?
Say, when were you born?

And what was your score
When you did VCE?
Did you study very hard,
Or did it come easily?

And where did you go
For your Bachelor's degree?
Of course, but of course:
Melbourne University!

One by one
The pieces come together
You're a handsome young man
And ever so clever.

But not enough numbers
Have I got from you.
For instance, can you tell me,
What's your IQ?
And what's your religion?
No, don't tell me you're a Jew!
I knew it, I knew it,
It's too good to be true!

I just had this feeling,
When I examined your face;
I could sense in you the presence
Of God's chosen race.
You know, Jews have this aura
I can pick it from a mile
It's the in shape of your noses
And your eyes when you smile.
And you're so good with money,
Success just falls in your laps
At my work the Jew accountants
Are such talented chaps.
But you know, you and I,
Have the same cast of mind:
My great uncle's fourth cousin
Was one your kind.
I think he was a Goldberg
Or maybe Riefenstahl
We don't know much about him
He was a gambling gull
So if you think about it
We're really kith and kin;
We practically inhabit
The very same skin.

And what was your degree in?
Were you top of the class?
Does the sun rise in the east,
Or shine from your arse?

And what do you make
On any given day?
Who covers your bills?
No, you pay your own way?
And what's this you tell me,
You live on your own?
But how do you manage
To do housework alone?

And who cooks your meals?
Surely not you yourself?
A young man like you
Lives on take out from his shelf.

OK, well maybe not all men,
Not specifically you,
But you know what I mean,
It's a good general rule
That what I presume
About your life
When we meet
Even though it's drawn from
A sample on the street,
Must apply to you as surely
As a bloodhound to a fox,
So do me a favour,
Would you mind climbing in this box
That I've work so many years on?
It's a very spacious cage.
And perhaps I've forgotten, but
What is your age?

entry.content:
Averted Eyes:

When you come you look away.
What would I see (I wonder)

Your groans are always stifled.

When lips are closed and eyes away;
When opened legs and stifled gasp
Accompany your desperate clasp.

And then my thoughts are put aside.

When you come, we like to kiss,
And miss each other's gaze.

Feverish Nights / Alex Garber
 
"There are times when he lies in his bed and he is overcome with an intense wave of loneliness.  Curled up under his blanket, he hugs his chest with a white-knuckled grasp as the relentless barrages of debilitating thoughts of eternal solitude besiege his consciousness. 

This is the pain of a lonely heart, punctured and emptied of its vital fluids of hope and trust, but still pumping out love on to a betrayal-heated mind.  Without the stabilising coolants of more encompassing emotions, the love becomes charred and poisonous like skin which burns, then heals and then becomes infected once more.

Shivering inside his freezing sticky cell he must wait until the fearful fever subsides.
It is these times that he misses her - when he is almost overwhelmed by the desire for human touch.  But she is not who she used to be, and the wondrous bond that once held them together now lies broken and battered under the weight of her arrogant abuse.  Now he must be strong, he cannot give in to his miserable heart; so bereft of a recipient for his affections. 
He is so used to giving of himself that he cannot anymore retain energies, like air hissing out from an over-inflated balloon, and so it leaks out to no one in particular. He has no chance, at this point, of his tenderness’s being reciprocated, and the balance between loving and being loved cannot possibly be maintained.

Eventually he gets up, washes his face in the bathroom and looks at himself in the mirror.  "I am not weak," he says to himself with a desperate yet fragile composure "It is just" he sighs to himself "that I get a little lonely sometimes".

entry.title: Solitary Snowstorm
entry.content:
Solitary Snowstorm:

A lone figure stands in the middle of the snowy fields, the creamy white sand capping his immobile head, nose bridge and shoulders as if he were a permanent fixture. I am frozen; when caught in a blizzard of misery, I found no love to shelter me – or perhapds I was not open to the love I could have had. I stumbled through the icy winds at first with hopeful determination only to find an increasingly large crack in my resolution with every slippery step. In this gaping hole my fear and hurt infested like a hundred tiny splinters in my chest; I could sense their presence and feel them prick me but I could do nothing to remove them without assistance. Eventually my frozen feet could take me no further nor could I retreat through the icy winds – in my haste to find refuge from myself I had not taken care to note my way over my bleak thoughts and had stumbled directionless through a uniform land. All around the snow-bedecked the world, leaving me as a blind man in an indistinguishable landscape. So I stopped and stood, arms hanging wearily at my sides and looked out towards the distance like a man marooned on an island; an eternal flower bud of hope nestling my eyes under the heavy snowy blanket of resignation on my face.
The wind swirled around, crooning with vicious delight as it flicked my face excitedly with spitting flurries of snowy fists. The knee deep snow around me hardened and looked my legs in place. I became mired in my misfortune and as time went by the snow around me rose higher and higher and yet I moved not an inch. The less I tried to strive forward the faster the wind blew and the harder it became to get out. I closed my eyes and waited for the difficulty to diminish. I didn’t feel I should expend my energies anymore. Everyda y the snow filled out around as if I were standing in a giant bowl and the skies were pouring the powdery snow on me from great suger sacks in the clouds.
I stand now shivering, up to my neck in my freezing thoughts but doing nothing to release myself.

Please. Sometimes my wintercoat of independence is simply not a good enough sustitute for the homely warmth of human kindness. So weatherbeaten am I by my misfortune I automaticaly repel all that comes near me, in order to protect myself, but if you could only warm my frozen face with sympathetic words or a tight embrace, then I am sure that I could return to chase, that special beckoning tiny place inside myself outside my thoughts that can stop the anger short...

You come from a distance through the howling hungry winds, like ravens for a fresh warm corpse, they crave the energy of your rosy cheeks. As you get to me, you find my body buried up to the neck in snow, my head swelling out like a white bulb which sprouts up from the ground. Slowly you approach me, the mired mushroom, and you place your hand on the snow that covers my face. Your hand kisses the snow’s surface, the natural body heat pushes it further through the covering. As the icy film laps up the heat from your palm the particles succumb to their inevitable parting of ways and after a short while, your hand seeps through onto my skin. My eyes open suddenly and I glare at you, innately suspicious of those few who grant me their honest attention.

Just a little longer I beg of you please, I need your warm faith or I shall soon freeze.
You fall back, frightened by my snarling reaction. It would be so easy to put your gloves back, button up your warm coat of self-preserving pride and wander off intact. This is a test of character, and you strive forward through the frost. You kneel down in front of me and place your hands back on my face. As I chill your hands, you soften my cheeks and eventually my snarl defrosts into a grimace and then melts into a smile. Kiss me. I need to feel that therapuetic warmth of tender human touch. I need to smell the warm perfume rising up from your neck and I long to pour my tenderness onto you through my hands, steaming away the snowy depression. You lean forward and let your mouth cover mine, your breath like a delicious hot chocolate floating up my face. My eyes close and I focus my body’s energy on our area of contact. You draw back and blanket my exposed head with your coat before you begin to dig around me.

This is what made me incomplete – the lack of purpose which made me weak, the missing link, the needed streak of pure desire to go out and seek...

I squirm and I shake, I watch the snow break around me while you dig away with endless devotion. Eventually my torso is liberated and I hold on to you tightly as we push and pull together to relinquish the snow’s grasp on my person. It has fastened around my legs so long that it releases me begrudgingly. Afterwards, I stand before you, smiling sheepishly in the oft-embarressing aftermath of an heroic effort. By now you are hot and have given me your outer clothing. Standing before each other, brought closer by the vast distance engulfing us it occurs to me how very much exposed you are.
I begin to unfasten the coat but before I can proffer it to you, you rest your hand on my shoulder. “Keep the coat. I will be warm until I get another one” I am confused and ask “where did you find such things?”
Her bare hands clasp my gloved ones. “You were caught out here because you had nowhere to go. You see nought but a frozen fields, whereas I have found my way.”
“Take me with you please” I request with an anxious edge to my voice as I gaze wide-eyed at her.
“I am sorry, but I could not,” you reply sadly “I have already found my niche and you are still searching. I must not deny you the opportunity to find your own place.”
You withdraw your grasp and your fingers slide away from mine.
“Where do I go on from here?”
“Where you are willing to take yourself.”
A moment of silent contemplation as I examine her soft lips and slender fingers.
“I need you.” I whisper.

She drops her gaze and smiles at the ground as she shakes her head. Snowflakes make their gentle earth-bound journeys around us as the wind blows forlorn puffs into my face. My vision blurs as she leans across to kiss me and as our lips meet I close my eyes. When I open them, she is gone and I stand alone, the snow falling onto my head and shoulders.

“What now?” I ask the world. “Why taunt me with useless hope, releasing me from my captivity only to leave me with little more than the meagre possessions which failed me before?”
“Now, I wouldn’t say that.” hums a voice which seems to come from all directions.
I am tired and bewildered and as I fall on to my knees I look down at the ground to find the image of an old man’s face with a great beard emerging through the surface. The face smiles benignly up at me. “




“Not this time.” I tell the world as I take my hardest step. “There is a place for me to go” while my heart beats in my chest. Despite the cold, my shoulders raised, I lift my hanging brow.
First, so hard to move my feet, as if I walk on glue.
Then, I move with some small ease, like propelling a canoe.
Next, my stride lengthens and my armor falls, unscrewed.
Now, I fly fast through the snow, refreshed, refilled, renewed.

It is never easier to keep on going, I know. Even if you have found your rhythm and you feel like you will never stop, something can easily knock you off your path. Then you must start all over again and you feel like conceding defeat and withdrawing from your journey. I wouldn’t blame you, no one can. It seems so easy to not pursue your destiny that you are often left wondering “why do I bother?” Sometimes you do give up. You take comfort in the fragile stability of freezing in the snow, but we both know that a life which succumbs to those things for which it was not designed is the hardest one of all. I accept that this is my home, out here, because I feel it in my heart. I do not see emptiness, as you do, but purity and it gladdens me. Go on, little man. Do not dwarf yourself against me and the vast spaces of my land. Your home awaits.

entry.title: At A Swing Dancing Workshop
Package to 3442
entry.content:
Herein you shall find a stick with a chip
With thousands of floating gate transistors
Formatted to standard NTFS
Although by me EXT4 would be
A better file system, more secure;
With in-built journalling for recovery,
Of photos of us on a sunny day
And clips of us kissing all morning in bed;
And line after line of raw sentiments,
Before they were compiled and found to have
Critical bugs and security flaws
That failed under the unforeseen stress
Of your family's run-time environment,
And the drain on our modest resources
By startup tasks that we never asked for.

I wonder now and then, at night, whether
We could have written our first drafts better,
Or possibly tried a little harder
But I think our source code was not too bad,
As it was, with all its faults and extra loops:
We could have corrected them in due course,
If our framework had been more workable;
If she had not been overclocked for nine months,
If the damn doctors had safely removed
That dying, defective, unstable mount,
Which should have never been there to start with,
But for the Pentecostal clamouring
That the Church has a long-standing patent
On who gets to live, and who gets to die,
And whose family gets to be ruined.

If only good advice had been followed
Early on, in this project's life cycle,
Which, I admit, started underfunded,
But got so much VC from its victory,
Fought long and hard for, we would all agree,
That you could have out-sourced all your grunt work,
And spent one-hundred-percent of your time
On the twenty-per-cent that you wanted;
Instead, you kept the QA to yourself
And put your ambitions on the high shelf,
And waited for your comfortable bubble
To burst one day and spatter everywhere,
And paint the picture as it always was.

But I knew none of that on our first chat,
And if I did know then what I have learned,
I think I still would have signed that contract,
Because in hindsight you are still beautiful,
As you are, with all your faults and extra loops,
And if we'd started with open source only,
And reported bugs from the outset without fear
Of the truth that messy code's not so bad
If the ideas behind it have merit.

And one day, just maybe, I dream sometimes,
We could take more photos on sunny days,
And make many more, silly, mini-films,
In bad lighting, with a cheap in-built mic,
And upload them to an online album,
Where they'd stay afloat, all day, in the cloud
While on the ground, we'd build our own OS,
With GCC, filled with Python and Perl;
It would be stable, resilient,
Configurable and fun to improve,
And we wouldn't worry about precise input,
Because our command line would be tolerant.

And I?
Well, I would be more forgiving.

entry.title: You Want To Be Heard
entry.content:
You want to be heard, 
But you haven't the words
You're big and strong but silent
When you open your mouth
The laugh and shout
But never listen -- listen!
Something's missing 
so we're going to find it out
With blunt verbs in your quiver
You try to deliver your message
But it drops like a stone
The words you assemble tell them
All they think they need to know
And when you're alone stuck in a queue 
Waiting your turn
To plead with a drone on the phone
For a little compassion its only reaction
Is a bundle of anesthetic phrases
And here's the translation:

This call is over
You're wasting your time
This is a line that you'll never cross
There's nothing you can say, not today, not tomorrow
So have a nice day, and don't forget to pay
As you hammer the table with the receiver
You hear the faint echo
Of inflated wallets
In bulging pockets
Laughing like greedy hyenas

You, you have no words that you have grown
You scoop yours from the FM blather
That scums the surface of your brain
As trundle home on the freeway
Or the freeze-dried music
In someone else's ears
In the crush of a rush-hour train
When you collapse on your couch
Unadulterated, unfettered thoughts break the surface
So you drown them with another helping
Of processed, dehydrated, microwave-oven television
Shipped in, in neat little packages,  across the Pacific
From our adopted Big Brother,
Where everything is bigger, stronger, louder, shinier, richer,
lonelier, poorer, angrier, and emptier too.

You, you don't own your words
You rent them
And pay more and more for fewer and less
When you try to release the burdens in your breast
Your expressions are eviscerated
Your phrases are amputated
Your feelings are decapitated
Gushing blood they writhe inside
Unable to stop, unwilling to die
No-one can know them
No-one can see them
No way of taking someone by the hand
And showing the dark clouds' approach
Instead you take people by the throat
And unleash your thunder and lightning storm

It feels good to be Thor, doesn't it?
It makes you feel raw
With your hammer of a hand 
That can land with a crash and a bang
And the crack of a skull on the floor
When they fall you stand tall

But how does it feel to hold pictures
And have letters slip through your fingers?
When work hard to get ahead
And have words fly over your head?
When you boast every day
That you can read looks
But fall silent at the hint
That you can't read books?
And what you hear you absorb
With ears tone-deaf and numb to
The discordant inferences
And parasitic untruths
That worm themselves into your brain

So you, yes you, you can blame and complain
But will you change?
Or stay the same?
Restricted to your range
Defined by your age
Classed by your sex
Believing in myths
Despising the truth
Accepting dishonesty
Preaching misanthropy
And sometimes misogyny (but only for fun)
While your curiosity atrophies
And your bitterness spreads to your bones?

But don't take my word for it, big man,
You, yes you, you need to grow up
And go find your own.

entry.title: The Conclusion
entry.content:
THE CONCLUSION / A. J. Garber

An old man sat in his study and wrote his final words:
“Soon my pen will run dry and the sun will set on me;
I shall not turn on my lamp, nor return to my work: it is ended.
That is my will; the skies are coloured by twilight’s approach:
That is my fate; the cover of night makes them plain1.”

He signed the bottom of the page,
but did not add his flourish;
his pen had run dry.

He sighed,
capped his pen,
and closed his book.

He laid his pen to rest, closed his bureau,
and covered it with a pure white cloth.
The sun sank into the window’s frame
and light flashed across its pane.

He sighed,
enclosed his glasses in their case,
and lowered them into his drawer.

He sat in his chair and watched the sun expire.
The light receded from his face;
in its place, the shadows lay;
on that day, came the night.

He folded his arms
and closed his eyes.
His head fell forward.
He smiled… and sighed.

entry.title: Words Thoughts Dreams
entry.content:
You want to be heard but words are elusive; you have no sounds to assemble, no verbs in your quiver, no arguments in your arsenal; you are bereft of the passport to the chambers of power.  But you still have time: here, take it to heart where it will be safe.

You can be ugly, you can be fat, you can be crippled, knocked back, held up, pushed down, but no-one can look you in the eye and confiscate ideas that you won't hand over, for words give you thoughts and thoughts give you freedom to be, to be, to be...

Not to be a no-one, not to be a number, not to be invisible, but to stake a claim on a space, to have a name, to have a face, to take your place amongst equals, to compete for first place if you want to -- if you can say it, you can think it, you can see it, smell it, taste it, touch it, from the depths of a squalorous cell to the dizzying heights and a galaxy of lights, your words can sustain your dreams, when everything shines with an oily glean, and all the world is dank and obscene you can remove yourself from this scene, and reclaim the latent reality in your heart.

If you can say it, you can think it, you can drink it in your sleep, you can find it in a heap of foiled plans and broken promises.

But you, you have no words to call your own.  You have gestures and sounds, and a hand-me-down persona from our big brother across the ocean, where everything of theirs is bigger, better, stronger, richer, faster, poorer, angrier, and emptier than ours.

You have no words to call your own.  You know some, you adopted some, but you are not their master, you're their mouthpiece; you don't own them, you rent them, and pay more and more for fewer and less.  You have feelings but no metaphors, you grasp pictures but letters slide through your fingers, you can read looks but you can't read books -- not in the way that allows you to say, "I understand and disagree", and not soak up resonant theories with tone-deaf ears to their discordant inferences and blatant untruths that worm themselves into your brain.

And so you blame, and complain, and show the world how big and strong and brave you are, but your edifice is built on shaky foundations, using borrowed blueprints from the government, and when you try to wrench the words from the ether and strike them to ring forth with clarity and veracity, you will find your liberty bell is cracked and you are small, and weak, and fearful in the forests of the night, when you face the tiger burning bright, and its beaming eyes meet yours, and its bloody breath burns your nostrils, it will call on you to rise up and repel its ferocious challenge with a veracious onslaught .

And you, you will fall silent under its gaze.
